title-group.article-title: Critical Care Issues in Managing Complex Open Abdominal Wound

abstract.p: Over the past 30 years, surgical specialties have introduced and expanded the role of open abdominal management in complicated operative cases, necessitating an intensivist’s understanding of the indications and unique intensive care unit (ICU) issues related to the open abdomen. When presented with the open abdomen, resuscitation to correct shock is of primary concern. This is accomplished by correction of hypothermia, acidosis, and coagulopathy in trauma and adequate resolution of intra-abdominal hypertension or source control in general surgery. These patients typically require deep sedation and often paralysis and benefit from low-volume ventilatory strategies to prevent and treat acute lung injury. Antibiotics must be tailored to the clinical situation, but in most cases, 24 hours of perioperative treatment is all that is required. In cases of gross contamination and peritonitis, a 5- to 7-day course of broad-spectrum antibiotics may be of benefit.Adequate source control has been demonstrated to have the greatest impact on outcome and when the patient’s clinical milieu dictates, bedside washouts. Enteral nutrition should be instituted as early as possible after intestinal continuity has been reestablished. Additional protein is required to account for losses from the open abdomen. Reconstruction may require staging, but in general, should proceed following resolution of shock and control of sepsis. Elevated multiorgan dysfunction score, Acute Physiology And Chronic Health Evaluation II (APACHE II), and a rise in peak inspiratory pressure portend poor source control and could result in failure of fascial closure. If unable to proceed to fascial closure, then considerations should be made for planned ventral hernia and subsequent abdominal wall reconstruction.

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Indications for the role of open abdominal management have included abdominal compartment syndrome (ACS) in its various forms, damage control surgery (DC), trauma inclusive of hepatic, severe non-hepatic, and penetrating abdominal trauma. Additionally, severe necrotizing pancreatitis, intra-abdominal sepsis, emergent vascular surgery, and recently even orthotopic liver transplantations have benefitted. Therefore, critical care providers must develop a general understanding of the indications, techniques, and management aspects of this technique.

Damage control is typically described as a 5-stage process, with the initial presentation and resuscitation occurring within the first 12 to 36 hours.1–3 Stage I consist primarily of defining the appropriate patient population and providing adequate temporary abdominal closure (TAC). Stage II is the most intensive portion of this process. It accounts for the postoperative resuscitation to include treatment of shock and open abdomen ventilatory strategies, sedation, and paralysis. The patient stability and potential need for bedside laparotomy must be defined. The use of antibiotics and their role in specific indications will be reviewed as well as the institution of nutritional support. Finally, the patient must be prepared for return to the operative theater and staged abdominal reconstruction. Stage III accounts for the reconstruction itself. We discuss the potential pitfalls and early warning signs of failure in fascial closure. Stages IV and V will be limited for the purpose of this review as they portend more to the rehabilitative aspects and techniques for achieving fascial closure and dealing with planned ventral hernias (Figure 1 ).

caption.p: Overview of the open abdomen technique.

sec.title: Pre-ICU Critical Care
sec.p: The initial resuscitation of the trauma/surgical patient requiring damage control surgery with an open abdomen technique occurs well before the patient arrives in the intensive care unit (ICU). Damage control resuscitation is initiated during the initial assessment of the patient in the emergency department. The acute coagulopathy of trauma-shock can be present in up to a quarter of patients with trauma,4,5 leading to a 4-fold increase in mortality and worse outcomes from traumatic brain injuries. Crystalloid-based resuscitation strategies were transitioned to balanced blood component transfusion during the Iraq war, including a 1:1 ratio of red blood cells (RBCs) to fresh frozen plasma (FFP). This aggressive correction of coagulopathy seems to dramatically reduce morbidity and mortality.6,7 Introduction of this strategy to civilian trauma centers has produced similar results reducing overall crystalloid infusion.8,9

In contrast, Scalea et al10 prospectively evaluated 806 consecutive patients with trauma and found FFP: RBC ratio did not predict mortality even in patients receiving greater than 10 units RBCs. A more accurate evaluation of transfusion for postinjury coagulopathy may be limited to those transfusions occurring within the first 6 hours of injury rather than by 24 hours.11 This narrow time frame more accurately reflects the physiological derangements of coagulopathy. Improved survival has been demonstrated with ratios more closely approximating 1:2 to 1:3 FFP:RBC.11 A trauma exsanguination protocol (TEP) at our institution based on a 2:3 FFP:RBC ratio with a 1:1 platelet: RBC ratio has shown significant reduction in organ failure and postinjury complications, including ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), open abdomen, and ACS12–15 (Table 1 ).

sec.p: In the operating room, the decision to abbreviate the operation and to initiate damage control laparotomy must be made early and is based on the patient’s physiologic reserve. This is defined as an individual’s ability to tolerate injury and is a function of the patient’s preinjury status and comorbidities. These include age, gender, preexisting disease, and immunocompetence. Once a patient has depleted their physiologic reserve, death will soon follow. The clinical signs of physiologic exhaustion are hypothermia (temp <35°C), acidosis (pH ≤7.20), and clinical coagulopathy defined as nonsurgical bleeding. Instituting damage control well before reaching physiologic exhaustion, Asensio et al16 reported less hypothermia and fewer infectious complications, including intra-abdominal abscess and fistula formation, and subjectively less bowel edema. They were able to achieve definitive abdominal fascial closure during the initial hospital stay in a large percentage (93%) of patients with this management guideline.16

sec.title: Abdominal Compartment Syndrome
sec.p: Emergent decompressive laparotomy is the primary management of ACS. It results in improvement in lung dynamic compliance17 and may also be of benefit in the setting of increased intracranial pressure.18 Abdominal compartment syndrome is defined as sustained intra-abdominal pressure (IAP) >20 mm Hg (with or without an abdominal perfusion pressure [APP] <60 mm Hg) that is associated with new organ dysfunction/failure.19 Risk factors include shock, mechanical ventilation, and aggressive fluid resuscitation.20–27 Bladder pressures greater than 25 mm Hg are suggestive of ACS.18 Decompressing the abdomen results in a significant improvement in the cardiac index, tidal volume, and urine output, with a resultant decrease in bladder pressure, heart rate, central venous pressure, pulmonary artery occlusion pressure, peak airway pressure, partial pressure arterial carbon dioxide, and lactate.18

sec.title: Trauma
sec.p: In patients with severe abdominal trauma, the classic triggers for DC include acidosis with a pH of less than 7.20, transfusion of 10 or more units of packed red blood cells (pRBCs; estimated blood loss, 4 liters), and temperature of 35°C or lower.16,22,28 Utilizing these triggers has been shown to decrease operative time and reduce transfusions, as well as reduce length of stay, blood loss, infectious complications, and visceral edema.16,29 Survival is improved for open abdominal treatment of damage control patients when compared to fascia closure in those with equivalent injury severity score (ISS), revised trauma score (RTS), trauma revised injury severity score (TRISS), admission systolic blood pressure, operating room systolic blood pressure, and penetrating abdominal trauma index score.22,24,30 Of note, peak airway pressures were significantly decreased and compliance was improved.31,32

sec.title: Pancreatitis/Peritonitis
sec.p: In necrotizing pancreatitis, the open abdomen with serial laparotomies has been reported as safe and effective at decreasing intra-abdominal postoperative infectious complications.27,33–35 Descriptive studies have claimed salvage rates as high as 80%36 in small case series of necrotizing pancreatitis managed with an open abdomen and serial debridement with packing.27,34 This advantage has been disputed by reports of better survival with minimally invasive approach compared to open abdominal techniques in a multi-institutional retrospective study from the Netherlands.37 Regrettably, this study provided limited criteria for the selection of a particular surgical management strategy (computerized tomography severity index only) and did not account for physiologic severity of illness. A recent randomized controlled trial of 88 patients with necrotizing pancreatitis and suspected or confirmed infected tissue found a reduction in risk ratio for a composite of major complications in patients that underwent a step-up approach, which combines initial percutaneous drainage followed by minimally invasive retroperitoneal necrosectomy compared to open necrosectomy.38 However, the rate of death did not differ significantly, 19% step-up approach versus 16% in open necrosectomy, P = .70. A clear clinical advantage remains controversial and physiology will continue to dictate the most appropriate approach for individual patients.

Serial washouts for other etiologies of peritonitis have been successful in improving the overall morbidity and mortality of the condition.3,20 Clinical parameters are suggestive of which patients have ongoing evidence of sepsis/inflammation after closure of the abdominal wall.39–41 Renal failure and increased multiorgan failure (MOF) scores are indicators that source control has not been achieved.42

sec.title: Vascular Emergency
sec.p: Early recognition and delayed abdominal closure have been shown to improve outcomes in ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (rAAA) patients with ACS.23 As in massively resuscitated trauma victims,22,23,27,30 delayed laparotomy closure in rAAA patients may confer a physiologic and survival benefit. Improved late outcome may be due to decreased pulmonary damage (improved PaO2/FiO2 [P/F] ratio) and improved tissue oxygenation (SvO2).21 Greater intraoperative blood loss, longer cross-clamp times, and longer operative time are risk factors for intra-abdominal hypertension (IAH), which often results in colonic ischemia. Earlier decompression as treatment of colonic ischemia may improve mortality.43 Patients with rAAA having IAH greater than 21 mm Hg (IAH >21 mm Hg) have demonstrated a better overall mortality when undergoing abdominal decompression.21,44

sec.title: Temporary Abdominal Closure
sec.p: The options for TAC are many, and include the “Bogotá bag” fashioned from a large IV fluid bag, a ready-to-use transparent “bowel bag,” vacuum-pack (VP) technique, synthetic mesh (absorbable or non-absorbable), or a Velcro-type sheath as advocated by Wittmann et al.45 Many have since been abandoned or supplanted by newer techniques. Today, the most common techniques for TAC include: vacuum pack, Wittmann Patch (WP; Starsurgical, Burlington, Wisconsin) and Bogotá Bag. Borraez developed the Bogotá bag in 1984. The technique involves sewing a sterile plastic 3-L urologic irrigation bag to the fascia to form a fascial bridge. This technique is simple and inexpensive.46 It does have the potential for fascial trauma, as it requires sewing to the fascia. It has been used extensively for trauma47 and abdominal sepsis.48 Besides IV bags, silastic sheeting has been used in a similar manner to the Bogotá bag by a number of authors to achieve a tension-free TAC.21,23,49–51 This technique is safe, has reasonably low incidence of bowel injury, and adhesion formation. However, fascial closure rates are low (28%-40%) in most series.48,50,51

Use of the Wittmann Patch was first reported in 1990 for use with serial abdominal washout for severe peritonitis.45,52 The WP consists of 2 sheets of hook and burr material (similar to Velcro) that is sewn to the fascial edges after a plastic drape is placed over the viscera. The hook and burr are overlapped with limited tension to provide a secure TAC. Gauze is used to pack the subcutaneous tissue.45 Pulling the Velcro-like material apart allows for easy and rapid reexploration of the abdomen. At the completion of the subsequent operations, the patch can be tightened to keep fascial tension. The Wittmann Patch has been associated with low complication rates, few enterocutaneous fistulas, and improved rates of fascial closure.53,54

The VP technique, first described in 199555 and a larger study in 1997,56 used a 3-layer TAC. Fascial closure rates are very good, with no difference and less complications.57–60 It facilitates patient movement and even prone positioning if necessary.61 This dressing has gained wide acceptance since it is easy and rapid to apply, inexpensive ($50 per application), atraumatic, and allows for excellent control of abdominal fluids.57,59 Vacuum pack remains the most popular TAC used today for trauma and emergency general surgery. It is the current standard of care for TAC. A commercial version of the VP has been manufactured, the VAC Abdominal Dressing System from KCI (San Antonio, Texas).57,62,63

sec.title: Stage II: ICU Resuscitation/Management of the Open Abdomen Patient
Initial Postoperative Resuscitation
sec.p: Upon arrival in the ICU, management strategies include (1) ongoing resuscitation and correction of hypothermia coagulopathy and acidosis; (2) ventilatory management including the use of sedation, analgesia and neuromuscular blockade; (3) fluid management; and (4) appropriate use of antibiotics to reduce infectious complications (Table 2 ).

Correction of coagulopathy: blood product resuscitation
Correction of hypothermia: passive vs active re-warming
Monitoring for abdominal compartment syndrome (ACS): primary, secondary and tertiary

Nutrition support of the open abdomen

sec.p: Standard resuscitation techniques in the ICU include correction of hypothermia with both active and passive rewarming techniques. Our protocol is to place the extremities into plastic bags to decrease evaporative heat loss. Air warmers are placed on the ventilator circuit and Bair Hugger therapy is instituted to aid to the passive warming. The Vac pack technique decreases heat loss through the open abdominal wound. Active rewarming may include intracorporeal infusion of warm fluids (warm saline bladder irrigation and gastric lavage) and/or the use of SIMS Lever 1 infuser to infuse warmed IV fluids and rewarm pRBC and FFP. Rarely, a patient in extreme hypothermia may need to be placed on cardiopulmonary bypass.

Fresh frozen plasma and platelets are used to correct coagulopathy and measurement of arterial lactate levels assist in measuring the adequacy of resuscitation. However, there continues to be controversy on how to best manage fluid balance in this patient population. Several prospective trials in acute lung injuries and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) favor a restrictive fluid management strategy, though no specific study has addressed fluid management related to the open abdomen.64–66

The use of pulmonary artery catheters in goal-directed therapy should be individualized and utilized primarily in those who need clarification. Vasopressor therapy is indicated to maintain mean arterial pressure ≥65 mm Hg in adequately resuscitated patients.67 Patients who continue to be unresponsive to vasopressor management may be adrenal insufficient. This may be one of the few indications for early use of IV steroids.67

sec.title: Ventilatory Support
sec.p: Ventilatory support should be tailored to the specific disease process. Strategies to minimize acute lung injury (ALI) and ARDS associated with the inflammatory response are suggested. The ARDS network has shown that a low tidal volume (5-6 mL/kg body weight) significantly reduces morbidity and mortality associated with ALI and ARDS.64,65 Critically ill patients are at constant risk of ALI which can be exacerbated by ventilator-acquired pneumonia or a transfusion-related ALI. Ventilatory modes utilizing either a pressure control or pressure-supported technique to achieve these low tidal volumes are acceptable. Occasionally, neuromuscular blockade must be utilized in the management of the open abdomen with worsening ALI. Periodic measurements of peak inspiratory pressures, as well as continuous monitoring of bladder pressures, should be performed to identify a secondary ACS.68

sec.title: Protocol for Open Abdomen—Sedation, Anxiolytics, and Paralysis
sec.p: Almost universally, these patients are critical ill, ventilated with degrees of ALI, and are in hemodynamic shock. During the initial resuscitation period, cardiac, pulmonary, and renal organ function is closely monitored. Additional ICU goals include pain control with reduction of agitation, stress, and fear. In our institution, a standard IV analgesia sedation protocol consists of the combined infusion of Fentanyl and Midazolam. We utilize the Richmond Agitation Sedation Scale (RASS) to determine the level of sedation and adjust the infusion accordingly. The utilization of the RASS score has been shown to decrease ICU length of stay (LOS).69 Propofol may also be used in addition to, or as an alternative to, Midazolam, with frequent neurologic evaluation, as warranted. A bispectral index (BIS) monitor (Aspect Medical Systems of Natick, Massachusetts) is designed to measure the effects of anesthesia on a patient’s level of consciousness by monitoring the patient’s brain activity. However, the effectiveness of the BIS monitor to reduce anesthesia awareness has been called into question. In a study of over 19 000 patients under anesthesia, the incidence of awareness has been reported as 0.13%.70 It is interesting that the BIS-monitored group (40%) had a higher incidence of awareness (0.18%) than the control cohort (0.1%).70 Avidan et al71 randomized 2000 patients undergoing anesthesia to a BIS-based protocol versus end-tidal anesthetic gas (ETAG) protocol and could not demonstrate a significant difference in anesthesia awareness for patients at high risk for this complication. The BIS monitor has been used in the critical care setting and has reduced the average cost of sedatives, as well as reduced the recall of unpleasant experiences, while maintaining adequate sedations levels.72–75 We utilize the BIS monitor to asses for adequate sedation when our patients are paralyzed and unable to communicate awareness.

sec.title: Bedside Laparotomy
sec.p: The patient with an open abdomen should be assessed daily for possible fascial closure. The laparotomy can be performed in the operating room or at the bedside based on the patient’s clinical status. Definitive procedures such as gastrointestinal anastomosis and unpacking of critical injuries should be performed in the operating room, as lighting and surgical instrumentation is ideal. If the patient’s status remains critical and re-laparotomy must take place in the ICU,2,76 a “Protocol for Bedside Procedures” (Figure 2) should be in place.3 In our ICU, a registered nurse (RN) trained to set up the sterile instrumentation and a sterile perimeter is required, with a separate RN to monitor the patient’s vital signs and the respiratory therapist to manage ventilator issues that may arise.3,76 In the setting of pancreatitis or intra-abdominal sepsis, routine daily abdominal washout may be performed. We recommend initially performing a large normal saline (NS) irrigation to decrease the contamination level and a thorough evaluation of the viscera and the subdiaphragmatic space to washout potential abscesses.39–41,77,78

sec.title: Antibiotics
sec.p: Antibiotic use should be directed toward the underlying disease process that culminated in the open abdomen. Apart from current recommendations for perioperative antibiotics, the open abdomen does not warrant any additional period of antibiotic coverage. Patients at risk for Enterococcal infection include those with postoperative intra-abdominal infection, those with recurrent gastrointestinal perforation, those with high Acute Physiology And Chronic Health Evaluation II (APACHE II) scores, and those receiving immunosuppressive medications79 (Table 3 ).

list-item.p: No hollow viscous injury—prophylactic (<24 hours) antibiotic coverage for skin flora.
Bowel injury with spillage—prophylactic (<24 hours) coverage for both gram negative enteric and anaerobic organisms.
Peritonitis—continued antibiotics covering both gram-negative enteric and anaerobic bacteria until source control achieved.
Vascular graft—prophylactic (<24 hours) coverage for skin flora.

sec.p: In addition, it seems reasonable that patients with significant prior antibiotic exposure would be more likely to have Enterococcus infections and should be considered for routine empiric anti-enterococcal coverage.79,80 Imipenem/Cilastatin, Ampicillin/Sulbactam, Piperacillin/Tazobactam, and Moxifloxacin provide reliable Enterococcal coverage. Vancomycin or Ampicillin can be added when it is believed to be necessary to provide additional Enterococcal coverage. Vancomycin-resistant Enterococci are only rarely identified in intra-abdominal infections, usually in the setting of tertiary peritonitis and prior antimicrobial exposure. If this pathogen is cultured, Linezolid or another antibiotic to which the organism is sensitive can be added.

Fungal peritonitis is encountered primarily in patients whose infections developed while they were receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics.81 For patients with complicated intra-abdominal infection managed by the open abdomen technique, no unique antibiotic strategies are recommended. Therapy should be limited to 4 to 7 days, as was recommended in the Surgical Infection Society (SIS) and Infectious Disease Society of America (IDSA) guidelines for complicated intra-abdominal infections.82,83 In those that meet the criteria for severe sepsis, Drotrecogin alfa [activated] (recombinant human activated protein C [aPc]) appears beneficial.84,85 Recommendations for cessation and resumption of aPc in conjunction with procedures must be observed in procedure-related bleeding ranges from 38% to 69%.

A recent study on the current state of the open abdomen by Teixeira found that independent risk factors associated with failed abdominal closure included the presence of a deep soft tissue infection or intra-abdominal abscess.86 However, there was no difference in the complication rate between prophylactic and prolonged antibiotic use.86 Interestingly, over 50% of the patients that failed to achieve definitive fascial closure developed an entero-atmospheric fistula.

In a review of a large series of open abdomen patients, Vogel et al87 found that the inability to achieve primary abdominal closure was associated with infectious complications (VAP, blood stream infection [BSI] and surgical site infection [SSI]) and large transfusion requirements. These health care−associated infections are a major preventable patient safety issue in the United States. Recent studies have shown that quality improvement initiatives can significantly reduce health care−associated infections, mortality, and cost.88–91 We recently described the development and implementation of an evidence-based practice to reduce health care−associated infections in critically injured patients reinforced with an online compliance-monitoring system.92,93 Additionally, several prospective and multiple retrospective studies have shown that a blood transfusion increased the risk of postoperative bacterial infection, ARDS, and death.94–100 These studies have encouraged institutions to develop restrictive transfusion policies in critically ill patients. Once active bleeding has been controlled, physiologic derangements corrected, and hemodynamic stability restored, the risk of blood transfusion outweighs its benefit.

sec.title: Nutrition Support of the Open Abdomen
sec.p: Nutrition support should be started once resuscitation is nearly complete, with correction of hypothermia, acidosis, and coagulopathy. In patients who have undergone damage control surgery where the gastrointestinal (GI) tract is left in discontinuity, enteral feeds will need to be held until GI continuity is reestablished. In patients with an intact GI tract, studies have shown it is safe to feed the patient with the open abdomen. These benefits appear to decrease time for abdominal fascial closure, decrease fistula rate, and lower pneumonia rate,101,102 with no significant difference in multiorgan dysfunction syndrome, length of ventilator days, ICU days, hospital days, or mortality.103

We can infer from a relatively recent study104 that the open abdomen represents a significant source of protein/nitrogen loss in the critically ill. Failure to account for this loss in nutritional calculations may lead to underfeeding and inadequate nutritional support with a direct effect on patient outcome. Although direct measurement of abdominal fluid protein loss may be optimal, an estimate of 2 g of nitrogen per liter of abdominal fluid output should be included in the nitrogen balance calculations of any patient with an open abdomen.104

sec.title: Stage III: Re-laparotomy/Staged Abdominal Reconstruction
sec.p: Patients are prepared to return for reconstruction of internal injuries40,42 when they have been adequately resuscitated, as demonstrated by correction of hypothermia, acidosis, and coagulopathy.28,1 This can usually be accomplished within 36 hours,1 although our more recent practice has demonstrated earlier normalization. This may be, in part, related to utilization of transfusion exsanguination protocols15 and minimized addition of crystalloid fluids.13,14,105 Injured devitalized tissue is resected and gastrointestinal injuries can be anastomosed safely, mitigating the necessity for obligate ostomy. However, in high-risk patients, ostomy remains the most conservative approach.106

Staging abdominal reconstruction serves 3 main functions: (1) reduces contamination and controls intra-abdominal sepsis, (2) debridement of devitalized or contaminated tissue, and (3) reconstruction. These techniques have been shown to improve outcomes in severely injured trauma patients.107 Re-laparotomy with routinely scheduled abdominal washout has been utilized as a means to effectively manage the patient with severe intra-abdominal sepsis. It is well tolerated with few GI complications and decreased mortality.40,52,108–111 Utilization in severe necrotizing pancreatitis has correlated with decreased mortality, although there are mixed results in less severe cases.35,41,78,112

Source control remains the priority in most patients managed with an open abdomen. Clinical parameters such as renal dysfunction, APACHE II, and multiorgan dysfunction score (MODS) may be predictive of ongoing intra-abdominal sepsis113–115 and can be used as indications for re-laparotomy.2,42,52,106,108 Holzheimer and Gathof,42 found patients that tolerated fascial closure had significantly lower scores than those with ongoing sepsis APACHE II 13.3 ± 7 vs 19.3 ± 7.1, MOF 2.2 ± 2.3 vs 5.4 ± 2.8, MODS 3.3 ± 4 vs 8.2 ± 4.8, PEEP 8.8 vs 11.5 Torr and repeat laparotomy reduced mortality. Those patients with advanced ventilatory demands may safely undergo bedside re-laparotomy with risks similar to those in the operative theater.2

Among the areas of controversy is an ongoing debate between planned (scheduled) re-laparotomy and on-demand (returning only for specific indications). A clear benefit has not been demonstrated for either.116 On-demand re-laparotomy did have a substantial reduction in re-laparotomies, health care utilization, and medical costs.116 This is predominantly demonstrated in the reduction of negative laparotomies. However, not a significantly lower rate of death or major peritonitis-related morbidity compared with the planned re-laparotomy group. Patients in the on-demand group typically had shorter median ICU stays and shorter median hospital stays.116

Managing complex open abdominal wounds requires a broad understanding of surgical decision making as well as the more focused aspects of critical care. These are complex patients requiring individualized care. We hope that the methods suggested here will assist in management of this diverse and complex patient population.
